newsitem.title: HONG KONG: HK short govt paper yields up on tight liquidity.
newsitem.headline: HK short govt paper yields up on tight liquidity.

text.p: Yields of short-dated Hong Kong government paper rose on Friday as liquidity was squeezed by initial public offerings (IPOs) of shares, dealers said.
One-week Exchange Fund bills yielded notably higher at 4.95 percent versus 4.87 at Thursday midsession.
Hong Kong dollar liquidity was tightened as funds were siphoned to the many of IPOs being launched, dealers said.
The Hong Kong Monetary Authority injected HK$107 million into the money market this morning, citing tight liquidity.
Yields of longer-end papers were sluggish, but slightly higher in line with U.S. Treasuries, they said.
Three-year notes yielded 6.38 percent versus 6.36, and five-year notes yielded 6.95 percent versus 6.94,
Yields of seven-year Exchange Fund notes yielded 7.31 percent versus 7.30.

Overnight cash rates edged up to 5-5/16 1/4 percent from 5-1/4 3/16, with the upside curbed by HKMA's injection, a dealer said. Three-month rates also traded marginally higher at 5-9/16 1/2 percent versus 5-1/2 15/32.
